column1: Title: State Requirements for Insurance Coverage of Contraceptives | KFF

column2: State Requires Coverage of Prescription Contraception
column3: State Requires Coverage of Over-the-counter Methods
column4: State Requires Coverage of Male Sterilization
column5: State Requires Coverage of Female Sterilization

column1: States have historically regulated insurance, and many have mandated minimum benefits for decades. Currently, 30 states require insurance plans to cover contraceptives, with a wide range of coverage and cost-sharing requirements, and exemptions among these mandates. Ten of these states and DC have passed laws expanding the ACA contraceptive coverage provision.

KFF analysis of state laws; [Insurance Coverage of Contraceptives](https://www.guttmacher.org/state-policy/explore/insurance-coverage-contraceptives), Guttmacher Institute, State Policies in Brief, as of May 1, 2022.
*Coverage Required for Prescription Contraception*: States that require insurance policies that cover prescription drugs to also cover all FDA-approved contraceptive drugs and devices.
*N/A*: Not applicable. State does not have a contraceptive coverage requirement for insurers that cover prescription drugs.
1. The states allow pharmacists to prescribe and dispense contraceptives, but insurance coverage of these services is not explicitly included in the law
2. These states exclude the coverage of external condoms
3. The states explicitly include coverage for contraception that is prescribed and dispensed by a pharmacist.
4. This state only provides coverage to over the counter drugs.
5. This state only provides coverage to over the counter condoms.
6. These states exclude the coverage of condoms.
